request_pathways.name: Authorization to Use or Disclose Health Information

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: A single generic HIPAA authorization form for disclosure to third parties, with a 'my personal records' purpose checkbox but no dedicated patient self-access pathway.

red_flags: Witness signature line present which may deter patients who lack an available witness
No submission instructions on the form — no fax number, address, email, or department listed
bright_spots: Explicit voluntariness statement: signing is voluntary and will not affect treatment
Easy findability: clearly labeled download button 2 clicks from homepage

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation — form was clearly linked on the Health Records page with a descriptive button label, reachable in 2 clicks from the homepage via a site-scoped search.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: Primarily a paper workflow — the form is an image-only scan with zero fillable fields, requiring printing and handwriting; no electronic submission method is documented on the form itself.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Adequate but with notable problems — single-page 10-item numbered list has logical flow, but lacks section headers or visual grouping, mixes plain language with legal phrasing, and provides no instructions for patient self-access use.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 2: Patient self-access is an afterthought — the form is a generic third-party authorization that asks for a recipient name/address; the 'my personal records' purpose checkbox is the only nod to self-access, with no guidance on how to use the form for that purpose.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Some requirements that may go beyond legal necessity — witness signature line (not required by HIPAA), no fee disclosure, no mention of response timeframes or patient access rights, though nothing clearly violates patient rights.

overall.summary: Colquitt Regional Medical Center offers an easily findable but technically poor records request form — a scanned image with no fillable fields, no submission instructions, and no differentiation between patient self-access and third-party release.
